FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: The propane tank is in an aboveground bunker that has a 1 foot thick, 8 foot high steel-reinforced concrete wall around it.  There is sand and soil surrounding the tank.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: The propellant process tanks and piping

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR PROGRAM  3 PRODUCTION PROCESS

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at our facility: This facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LP-Gas storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the Valley Park Fire Protection District Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.

A description of our facility and the regulated substances handled:  This facility is an insecticide manufacturer for use by commercial applicators.  We use a number of different propellants in our aerosol insecticide can products.  We have one 12,000 gallon isobutane/propane mixture  tank (A-46), one 12,000 gallon demethyl ether tank (DME), three 2,000 gallon propane  tanks (A-108), and one 2,000 gallon difluouroethane tank (Dymel 152A).  The two 12,000 gallon tanks are located in aboveground bunkers. 

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios: A worst-case analysis was done for each flammable propellant above the threshold.  The propellant with the greatest offsite consequence radius was chosen for the worst-case scenario which in this case was the 12,000 gallon isobutane/propane tank (A-46).  Originally, the A-108 propane was stored in this tank, but a change in operations led to switching the A-108 into the 2,000 gallon tanks and the A-46 into the 12,000 gallon tank.  This changed the worst-case distance to endpoint and the RMP Level 3 program had to be updated.  The failure of the 12,000 gallon isobutane/propane tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (88% at 60 degrees F), results in a vapor cloud explosion.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.  Our alternative release scenario is a break in a 2-inch diameter pipe from the 12,000 gallon isobutane/propane tank, leading to a 10-minute release and explosion of some of the re

leased propellant.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The propellant system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA 58 and state law.

Five-year accident history:  We have never had an accident involving the propellant system that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place.

The emergency response program:  In the event of an emergency involving our propellant system, it is our policy to notify the Valley Park Fire District Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.  We have discussed this policy with the fire department and they are aware of their responsibility.     

Planned changes to improve safety: A water deluge system was installed over the vertical propellant tanks in 2000.  The gas detection system in the gashouses has been replaced with better equipment.


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR PROGRAM  1 WAREHOUSE PROCESS

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at our facility: This facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LP-Gas storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  The packaging and storing of the aerosol cans follow accepted industry standards.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the Valley Park Fire Protection District Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.

A description of our facility and the regulated substances handled:  This facility is an insecticide manufacturer for use by commercial applicators.  We use a number of propellants in our insecticide aerosol can products.  We chose propane as a representative sample since it has the worst-case impac

t.  The quantity of cans stored in our warehouse puts us over the 10,000 lbs propane threshold.

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios: We have one worst-case scenario for this location.  It is a failure of one, 2 lb can of pesticide with 1 lb of propellant.  The failure of a can in a fire results in an endpoint of 43 feet so it does not extend offsite.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The isobutane/propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA 58 and state law.  The warehouse follows accepted industry standards in packaging and storing the aerosol insecticide products.

Five-year accident history:  We have never had an accident involving the warehouse aerosol propellant storage areas that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place.

The emergency response program:  In the event of an emergency involving our warehouse facility, it is our policy to notify the Valley Park Fire District Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.  We have discussed this policy with the fire department and they are aware of their responsibility.     

Planned changes to improve safety: None.
